factoid: Mary Bogdánovna instructed the messenger to inform the prince that labor had begun.
Mary Bogdánovna gave the messenger a significant look.
Tíkhon went to the prince and told him that labor had begun.
The prince said "Very good!" while closing the door behind him.
Tíkhon did not hear any sound from the study after that.
Tíkhon re-entered the study as if to snuff the candles.
Tíkhon saw that the prince was lying on the sofa.
Tíkhon looked at the prince.
Tíkhon noticed the prince's perturbed face.
Tíkhon shook his head.
Tíkhon went up to the prince silently and kissed him on the shoulder.
Tíkhon left the room without snuffing the candles or saying why he had entered.
The most solemn mystery in the world continued its course.
Evening passed.
Night came.
The feeling of suspense and softening of heart in the presence of the unfathomable increased.
No one slept.
It was a March night when winter seemed to wish to resume its sway.
Winter scattered its last snows and storms with desperate fury.
A relay of horses had been sent up the highroad to meet the German doctor from Moscow.
The German doctor from Moscow was expected every moment.
Men on horseback with lanterns were sent to the crossroads to guide the doctor over the country road.
The country road had hollows and snow‑covered pools of water.
Princess Mary had put aside her book.
Princess Mary sat silent.
Princess Mary's luminous eyes were fixed on her nurse's wrinkled face.
Princess Mary's luminous eyes were fixed on the lock of gray hair that escaped from under the kerchief.
Princess Mary's luminous eyes were fixed on the loose skin that hung under her chin.
Nurse Sávishna was knitting in hand.
Nurse Sávishna was telling in low tones.
Nurse Sávishna was scarcely hearing or understanding her own words.
Nurse Sávishna told that the late princess had given birth to Princess Mary in Kishenëv.
The late princess had given birth to Princess Mary in Kishenëv with only a Moldavian peasant woman to help instead of a midwife.
Nurse Sávishna said that God is merciful and doctors are never needed.
A gust of wind beat violently against the casement of the window.
The double frame of the window had been removed.
The double frame had been removed by order of the prince.
One window frame was removed in each room as soon as the larks returned.
The gust of wind forced open a loosely closed latch.
The gust of wind set the damask curtain flapping.
The gust of wind blew out the candle.
The candle blew out with a chill snowy draft.
Princess Mary shuddered.
Nurse Sávishna put down the stocking she was knitting.
Nurse Sávishna went to the window.
Nurse Sávishna leaned out of the window.
Nurse Sávishna tried to catch the open casement.
The cold wind flapped the ends of Nurse Sávishna's kerchief.
The cold wind flapped her loose locks of gray hair.
Nurse Sávishna said that there was someone driving up the avenue.
Nurse Sávishna said that the person was with lanterns.
Nurse Sávishna said that the person was most likely the doctor.
Princess Mary said "Oh, my God! thank God!".
Princess Mary said that she must go and meet the doctor.
Princess Mary said that the doctor does not know Russian.
Princess Mary threw a shawl over her head.
Princess Mary ran to meet the newcomer.
While crossing the anteroom, Princess Mary saw through the window a carriage with lanterns standing at the entrance.
Princess Mary went out on the stairs.
A tallow candle stood on a banister post.
The tallow candle guttered in the draft.
Philip, the footman, stood on the landing below.
Philip, the footman, looked scared.
Philip, the footman, held another candle.
Beyond the turn of the staircase, one could hear a footstep of someone in thick felt boots.
A voice that seemed familiar to Princess Mary was saying something.
The voice said "Thank God!".
The voice said "And Father?".
Demyán the house steward replied that he was gone to bed.
The voice said something more.
Demyán replied.
The steps in the felt boots approached the unseen bend of the staircase more rapidly.
Princess Mary thought that it was Andrew.
Princess Mary thought that it cannot be Andrew because it would be extraordinary.
The face and figure of Prince Andrew appeared on the landing where the footman stood.
Prince Andrew wore a fur cloak with a deep collar covered with snow.
Prince Andrew was pale.
Prince Andrew was thin.
Prince Andrew had a changed expression.
Prince Andrew had a strangely softened but agitated expression.
Prince Andrew came up the stairs.
Prince Andrew embraced his sister.
Prince Andrew asked the princess, "You did not get my letter?".
Prince Andrew did not wait for a reply.
Prince Andrew would not have received a reply because Princess Mary was unable to speak.
Prince Andrew turned back.
Prince Andrew rapidly mounted the stairs again.
Prince Andrew was accompanied by the doctor who had entered the hall after him.
Prince Andrew and the doctor had met at the last post station.
Prince Andrew again embraced his sister.
Prince Andrew said, "What a strange fate, Másha darling!".
Prince Andrew took off his cloak.
Prince Andrew took off his felt boots.
Prince Andrew went to the little princess' apartment.
